facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 298 of 1955 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL Appeal No. 298 of 1955. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 28, 1953 of Patna High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 28, 1953, of the Patna High Court in Appeal from Original Order No. 90 of 1949

facts.text: Patna High Court appeal from Original Order No. 90 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: in Appeal from Original Order No. 90 of 1949, arising out of the judgment and order dated January 25, 1949, of the Sub-Judge, Purnea

facts.text: Sub-Judge Purnea passed judgment and order dated January 25, 1949 in Misc. Case No. 54 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: , arising out of the judgment and order dated January 25, 1949, of the Sub-Judge, Purnea, in Misc. Case No. 54 of 1947.

facts.text: Appeal arises out of execution proceeding under United Provinces Encumbered Estates Act, 1934 (U.P. XXV of 1934).

anchor.surface_text: This appeal arises out of a proceeding in execution of an adjudication made under the provisions of the United Provinces Encumbered Estates Act, 1934  U. P. XXV of 1934 ,

facts.text: Respondent was proprietor of landed properties in United Provinces entitled to relief under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The facts may number be stated. The respondent was the proprietor of landed properties in the United Provinces and was entitled to claim relief under the Act.

facts.text: Respondent became heavily encumbered in debts in 1926 and 1927 by creating mortgages to Allahabad Bank, Banaras Bank and Kalia.

anchor.surface_text: He became heavily encumbered in debts. It is number necessary to go into his financial embarrassment in great detail and it will be enough to say that in 1926 and 1927 he had created several mortgages

facts.text: In 1929, Banaras Bank filed suit against respondent in Court of Additional Sub-Judge, Banaras, making other creditors parties.

anchor.surface_text: In 1929, the Banaras Bank filed a suit against the respondent in the Court of the Additional Sub-Judge, Banaras, in the United Provinces for enforcement of its mortgage making the other creditors

facts.text: Decree passed in Banaras Bank suit giving creditors priority in certain order.

anchor.surface_text: of the respondent named above parties to the suit. A decree was passed in that suit giving the creditors priority in a certain order.

facts.text: Allahabad Bank appealed to High Court at Allahabad, decided in its favour.

anchor.surface_text: The Allahabad Bank number being satisfied with that order of priority, filed an appeal in the High Court at Allahabad which was decided in its favour.

facts.text: While Allahabad HC appeal pending, respondent applied to Collector of Banares for relief under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: While the appeal was pending, the respondent applied to the Collector of Banares for relief under the Act.

facts.text: On March 21, 1940, Special Judge of Banares passed three money decrees in favour of three creditors totaling nearly rupees nine lacs.

anchor.surface_text: and on March 21, 1940, the Special fudge of Banares to whom the application had been forwarded by the Collector, passed three money decrees in favour of the three creditors

facts.text: Special Judge sent decrees to Collector of Banaras for execution.

anchor.surface_text: He then sent the decrees to the Collector of Banaras for execution as required by the Act.

facts.text: Execution of decrees commenced by Additional Collector, Banaras against properties in United Provinces.

anchor.surface_text: The execution of the decrees was thereafter companymenced by the Additional Collector, Banaras under the provisions of the Act against the properties in the United Provinces.

facts.text: Respondent owns Semapur estate in district of Purnea in Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent owns an estate in the district of Purnea in Bihar, called the Semapur estate.

facts.text: Additional Collector, Banaras applied to Additional Civil Judge, Banaras for transmission of decrees to Subordinate Judge, Purnea; order made on January 4, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Collector, Banaras, applied to the Additional Civil Judge, Banaras, for transmission of the said decrees to the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Purnea for execution and an order for transmission

facts.text: On March 17, 1947, Additional Collector, Banaras applied to Subordinate Judge, Purnea to execute decrees by attachment and sale of Semapur estate.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on March 17, 1947, the Additional Collector, Banaras, applied to the Subordinate Judge, Purnea, as the transferee Court to execute the decrees by attachment and sale of the Semapur estate.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge, Purnea made order directing execution to issue.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge thereupon made an order directing execution to issue as sought.

facts.text: Respondent appealed to High Court at Patna from Subordinate Judge Purnea's order; appeal allowed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent preferred an appeal to the High Court at Patna from this order of the Subordinate Judge, Purnea and his appeal was allowed with the result that the execution

facts.text: Present appeal by Additional Collector, Banaras against Patna High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: of the decrees against the Semapur estate failed. The present appeal is by the Additional Collector, Banaras against the order of the High Court.

facts.text: Patna High Court held Subordinate Judge, Purnea did not have jurisdiction to execute the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises in this appeal is whether the Subordinate Judge, Purnea, bad jurisdiction to order execution of the decree transferred to him. The High Court held that he did number

facts.text: Execution continuously pending since decree sent to Collector by Additional Collector, Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that all along since the decree was sent by the Special Judge to the Collector for execution and before that date the decree was number executable it has companytinuously

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside Patna High Court order and restores Subordinate Judge Purnea's order.

anchor.surface_text: We think therefore that this appeal must succeed. We set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the Subordinate Judge, Purnea.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SARKAR, J. on March 16, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. March 16. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SARKAR, J.-This appeal arises out of a proceeding in execution
United Provinces Encumbered Estates Act, 1934  U. P. XXV of 1934 , an Act passed by the legislature of the United Provinces, number called the Uttar Pradesh.

issues.text: Whether the Subordinate Judge, Purnea, had jurisdiction to order execution of the decree transferred to him

anchor.surface_text: The first question that arises in this appeal is whether the Subordinate Judge, Purnea, had jurisdiction to order execution of the decree transferred to him. The High Court held that he did not have that jurisdiction. The matte

issues.text: Whether the order of transfer of the decree was invalid because it was not made on the application of the decree-holder

anchor.surface_text: It was then contended that the order of transfer of the decree was invalid because under s. 39 of the Code such an order could be made only on the application of the decree-holder and in the present case it had not

issues.text: Whether the decree could be transferred only by the Court which passed it and whether the order of transfer was made by the correct court

anchor.surface_text: The third point against the validity of the order of the learned Subordinate Judge was that under s. 39 of the Code the decree could be transferred only by the Court which passed it. It was said that in the present

issues.text: Whether the decree was barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was said that the decree was barred by limitation long before the order for its transfer was made. It was contended that art. 182 of the Limitation Act governed the case, and the application for its

arguments.claim: Subordinate Judge, Purnea, did not have jurisdiction to order execution of the decree because the decree was not a decree under the Code of Civil Procedure outside UP and s.14(7) of UP Encumbered Estates Act cannot apply in Bihar as it would give extra-territorial operation to UP legislation

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that he did not have that jurisdiction. The matter was put in this way. The decree was not a decree under the Code of Civil Procedure. It was only to be deemed as such because of s. 14 (7) of the Act. The Act was an Act of the United Provinces legislature which could not pass a legislation having effect outside the United Provinces.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: d therefore to be companyfined within the borders of the United Provinces. The Subordinate Judge, Purnea companyld number apply that section in Bihar

arguments.court_reasoning: No extra-territorial operation involved as transferee court applies UP Act to decree passed in UP; execution follows CPC which applies throughout India

arguments.claim: Order of transfer of decree invalid because under s.39 CPC it can only be made on application of decree-holder but was made on application of Additional Collector not Collector

anchor.surface_text: It was then contended that the order of transfer of the decree was invalid because under s. 39 of the Code such an order could be made only on the application of the decree-holder and in the present case it had not been made on his application.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of the decree was invalid because under s. 39 of the Code such an order companyld be made only on the application of the decree- holder and in the pr

arguments.court_reasoning: Additional Collector deemed to be Collector under ss.14 and 14A UP Land Revenue Act 1901 as Government directed him to exercise powers for execution under Encumbered Estates Act

arguments.claim: Decree could be transferred only by court which passed it i.e. Special Judge but transfer ordered by Additional Civil Judge Banaras who was not Special Judge

anchor.surface_text: The third point against the validity of the order of the learned Subordinate Judge was that under s. 39 of the Code the decree could be transferred only by the Court which passed it. It was said that in the present case it is only by virtue of s. 14 of the Act that the decision of the Special Judge is deemed to be a decree

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ctor, as the Government directs him to do. We have before us a document companytaining such an order by which the work of sale and execution which und

arguments.court_reasoning: Additional Civil Judge was the same court as Special Judge under notification; Special Judge deemed civil court which passed decree under s.39 CPC; mere irregularity

arguments.claim: Decree was barred by limitation under art.182 Limitation Act long before transfer order as application for execution made beyond time

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, it was said that the decree was barred by limitation long before the order for its transfer was made. It was contended that art. 182 of the Limitation Act governed the case, and the application for its execution had been made beyond the time limited.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: was companytended that art. 182 of the Limitation Act governed the case, and the application for its execution had been made beyond the time limited.

arguments.court_reasoning: Execution continuously pending since sent to Collector; application to Purnea court is continuation of pending execution by Collector; no fresh application under art.182; precedents support daily accruing right

arguments.claim: No question of limitation arises as execution proceeding in Purnea court is continuation of execution pending before Collector of Banaras

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that that article had no application to the present case and that no question of limitation arose for the execution proceeding in Purnea Court is merely a continuation of the execution proceeding pending before the Collector of Banares.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: if the application for execution with which we are companycerned was made in a pending execution proceeding, numberion of the application of art. 182

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; execution by Collector under Act deemed under CPC; transfer execution continues pending proceeding; right accrues daily per precedents Kedar Nath Dutt and Subba Chariar

arguments.claim: Special Judge is a civil court for purposes of s.39 CPC transfer as he adjudicates rights like civil court and Act contemplates execution outside UP

anchor.surface_text: Nor does there seem to be any objection to think that the Special Judge is a civil court. From the provisions of the Act earlier set out there is no doubt that he adjudicates upon rights of the parties and acts in the same way as any other civil court would do.

arguments.claim: Execution by Collector under Act within UP deemed execution under CPC; outside UP via transfer also continuation

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore clear that the only mode of execution of the decree within the United Provinces contemplated by the Act is the execution by the Collector. Within the United Provinces the execution of the decree by the Collector would be deemed to be an execution under the Civil Procedure Code.

arguments.claim: Precedents recognize right to continue pending proceeding accrues daily with no limitation bar

anchor.surface_text: It has long been recognised by the courts in our country that a right to continue a proceeding which is pending is a right which arises from day to day and no question of any bar of limitation with regard to the enforcement of such a right arises See Kedar Nath Dutt v. Harra Chand Dutt Subba Chariar v. Muthuveeran Pillai.

holdings.text: The Subordinate Judge, Purnea, had jurisdiction to execute the decree passed under the Act within the United Provinces and sent to him for execution

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore wrong in thinking that the Subordinate Judge, Purnea, had no jurisdiction to execute the decree passed under the Act within the United Provinces and sent to him for execution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No extra-territorial operation as transferee court applies UP Act to decree originating in UP; execution governed by central CPC applicable in Bihar

holdings.text: The order of transfer of the decree was valid as made on application of Additional Collector who is deemed the Collector

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Collector therefore exercises such of the powers and discharges such of the functions of the Collector, as the Government directs him to do. We have before us a document containing such an order by which the work of sale and execution which under the Encumbered Estates Act had to be done by a Collector, had been entrusted to the Additional Collector.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under UP Land Revenue Act ss.14,14A, Additional Collector exercises Collector's powers as directed by Government for execution under Encumbered Estates Act

holdings.text: The order of transfer of the decree is valid as made by the court which passed it, the Special Judge being the Additional Civil Judge

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore the same court which exercises the powers of an Additional Civil Judge as also those of a Special Judge under the Act. We find no difficulty in treating the order of transfer as having been made by the Special Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notification conferred Special Judge powers on Additional Subordinate Judge (later Civil Judge); mere irregularity in nomenclature; Special Judge deemed civil court under CPC s.39

holdings.text: Special Judge is a civil court which passed the decree within meaning of CPC s.39

anchor.surface_text: Nor does there seem to be any objection to think that the Special Judge is a civil court. From the provisions of the Act earlier set out there is no doubt that he adjudicates upon rights of the parties and acts in the same way as any other civil court would do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special Judge adjudicates rights like civil court; Act deems decision a decree; execution outside UP contemplated by s.24(3)

holdings.text: The decree was not barred by limitation as execution in Purnea court is continuation of pending execution by Collector

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us therefore that the execution of the decree by the Collector must be deemed to be execution of a decree for all purposes and therefore an application made to the Subordinate Judge, Purnea, for execution of the same decree while an execution proceeding was pending before the Collector, must be a continuation of the execution last mentioned.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Execution continuously pending since sent to Collector; Collector execution deemed under CPC; transfer continues proceeding; right accrues daily per precedents (Kedar Nath Dutt, Subba Chariar)

precedents.citation: Kedar Nath Dutt v. Harra Chand Dutt 1

Harra Chand Dutt 1

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore wrong in thinking that the Subordinate Judge, Purnea, had no jurisdiction to execute the decree passed under the Act within the United Provinces and sent to him for execution.
We think therefore that this appeal must succeed. We set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the Subordinate Judge, Purnea.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Collector therefore exercises such of the powers and discharges such of the functions of the Collector, as the Government directs him to do. We have before us a document containing such an order by which the work of sale and execution which under the Encumbered Estates Act had to be done by a Collector, had been entrusted to the Additional Collector.
We think therefore that this appeal must succeed. We set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the Subordinate Judge, Purnea.

anchor.surface_text: It is therefore the same court which exercises the powers of an Additional Civil Judge as also those of a Special Judge under the Act. We find no difficulty in treating the order of transfer as having been made by the Special Judge.
We think therefore that this appeal must succeed. We set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the Subordinate Judge, Purnea.

anchor.surface_text: Nor does there seem to be any objection to think that the Special Judge is a civil court. From the provisions of the Act earlier set out there is no doubt that he adjudicates upon rights of the parties and acts in the same way as any other civil court would do.
We think therefore that this appeal must succeed. We set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the Subordinate Judge, Purnea.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us therefore that the execution of the decree by the Collector must be deemed to be execution of a decree for all purposes and therefore an application made to the Subordinate Judge, Purnea, for execution of the same decree while an execution proceeding was pending before the Collector, must be a continuation of the execution last mentioned.
We think therefore that this appeal must succeed. We set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the Subordinate Judge, Purnea.
